thread.title: Yoenis Cespedes not afraid of Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw, Zack Greinke
thread.title_full: Yoenis Cespedes not afraid of Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw, Zack Greinke

author: azcentral.com
title: Yoenis Cespedes not afraid of Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw, Zack Greinke
text:
LOS ANGELES — Yoenis Cespedes did not mean it as a dare but simply as a statement of fact. Yes, the Los Angeles Dodgers may have two of the three best pitchers in the National League, but they also have to deal with him.
A day after the Chicago Cubs’ Jake Arrieta overwhelmed the Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League wild-card game, the prospect of Dodgers co-aces Clayton Kershaw and Zack Greinke similarly dominating the New York Mets looms over this NL Division Series.
Not so fast, Cespedes said.
:To me, they’re pitchers like any others," Cespedes said in Spanish. "Everybody knows how good they are, but they still have to throw it down there just like they all do."
USA TODAY
Dodgers' Clayton Kershaw to start Game 1 of NLDS
While Kershaw and Greinke combined to go 2-0 with an 0.90 ERA in four starts against the Mets this season, all those games took place before a July 31 trade that sent Cespedes to New York. His arrival, combined with David Wright’s return and the contributions of late-July acquisitions Kelly Johnson and Juan Uribe, helped transform the meekest offense in the NL into the most potent one.
Cespedes hit 17 homers and drove in 44 runs in 57 games with the Mets, and his presence took pressure off other hitters in the lineup. That didn’t surprise Johnson, who was Cespedes’ teammate with the Boston Red Sox for a month last season.
"I told our general manager, Sandy Alderson, when it happened how excited I was for us to get this guy, because I knew the impact he could have and how special he was," Johnson said. "Not a lot of people in the game can do what he can do. He’s a throwback talent. He does a lot of things every day to change games."
Cespedes, an impending free agent, embraces the extra attention and excitement that comes with playoff baseball. He hit .350 in 10 postseason games with the Oakland Athletics in 2012 and 2013, and said his teams in Cuba made the playoffs seven out of his eight seasons there.
"I like the ruckus (at the ballpark)," he said. "When there’s a lot of ruckus, my concentration goes to a higher level to where I can’t get distracted, because I can’t hear anything else."
GALLERY: BEST MOMENTS OF THE POSTSEASON
ALDS Game 1: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Rougned Odor (right) celebrates with Delino DeShields after hitting a solo home run in the 7th inning to give the Rangers a deciding 5-3 lead. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: The Cubs celebrate their first postseason win since the 2003 NLCS after defeating the Pirates 4-0. Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: Jake Arrieta becomes the first Cubs pitcher to throw a postseason shutout in 70 years, leading the Cubs to a 4-0 victory. Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: Cubs rookie Kyle Schwarber rounds the bases after hitting a majestic 450-foot two-run homer that landed in the Allegheny River in the third inning off Pirates' Gerrit Cole. Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: Cubs starter Jake Arrieta reacts after he was hit by a pitch by Pirates' Tony Watson in the seventh inning. "It’s the playoffs.There’s a lot at stake. Tempers are running hot. It’s just the environment. It breeds that kind of intensity, and sometimes those things happen." Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen AL wild-card game: On three days rest, Dallas Keuchel hurls six shutout innings of three-hit, seven-strikeout ball in Houston’s 3-0 victory over the Yankees. Adam Hunger, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen AL wild-card game: Astros outfielder Carlos Gomez hits a home run on the first pitch of the fourth inning off Yankees' Masahiro Tanaka that sails deep into the left field stands, silencing the capacity crowd. Appropriately, Gomez flips his bat and admires it. Adam Hunger, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Like this topic?
